  physical_appearance: This is a brown beret cap. It has a slanted round top
 with a circular fitting headband around the bottom. In the front
 there is a badge pinned to the beret. It features a tiger\u0027s head. Underneath the tiger is a semi-circular banner with the inscription of Malaya in Chinese
 English
 and Jawi script. There are no tears seen on the beret.

  sgcool_label_text: This cap belongs to part of a collection of artefacts owned by Chan Phui Kong and related to the World War II underground resistance movement known as Force 136. Chan’s collection forms part of a larger collection of materials gathered by Tan Chong Tee (1916- 2012)
 who was a key member of this resistance group. The collection consists of original materials belonging to Tan and other members of Force 136 dating from the 1940s to new materials reproduced from memory by Tan Chong Tee
 which date from the late 1980s to early 2000s. \r\n\r\nForce 136 was set up in July 1942 as part of the British Special Operations Executive (SOE). It recruited and trained local guerillas to gather intelligence and create an underground spy network to support planned British invasion of Japanese-occupied Malaya.

metadata.physical_appearance: This is a brown beret cap. It has a slanted round top, with a circular fitting headband around the bottom. In the front, there is a badge pinned to the beret. It features a tiger's head. Underneath the tiger is a semi-circular banner with the inscription of Malaya in Chinese, English, and Jawi script. There are no tears seen on the beret.

metadata.sgcool_label_text:
This cap belongs to part of a collection of artefacts owned by Chan Phui Kong and related to the World War II underground resistance movement known as Force 136. Chan’s collection forms part of a larger collection of materials gathered by Tan Chong Tee (1916- 2012), who was a key member of this resistance group. The collection consists of original materials belonging to Tan and other members of Force 136 dating from the 1940s to new materials reproduced from memory by Tan Chong Tee, which date from the late 1980s to early 2000s. 

Force 136 was set up in July 1942 as part of the British Special Operations Executive (SOE). It recruited and trained local guerillas to gather intelligence and create an underground spy network to support planned British invasion of Japanese-occupied Malaya.
